Award.AwardTitle: Harmonic Analysis and Elliptic Homogenization Problems
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project aims to study a class of elliptic homogenization problems in domains with non-smooth boundaries. The main focus will be on second order elliptic equations and systems with rapidly oscillating periodic coefficients in domains whose boundaries satisfy some geometric conditions (for example, Lipschitz). The primary objective of this project is to gain a better understanding of the boundary regularity properties of solutions by establishing uniform estimates under physically realistic assumptions. Boundary value problems in non-smooth domains have received extensive study in the last 30 years. However, very few results are known for elliptic equations and systems with rapidly oscillating periodic coefficients, which arise in the theory of homogenization. The dilation-invariant property of the family of elliptic operators and that of the class of Lipschitz domains make problems to be investigated very interesting and challenging. The proposed research lies at the interface of harmonic analysis and partial differential equations.

In many applied problems of elasticity, aero- and hydrodynamics, and electro-magnetic wave scattering, the boundary value problems for the partial differential equations are posed in domains whose boundaries have faces, edges, and vertices. The class of Lipschitz domains is a dilation invariant class which allows such roughness on the boundaries. The results of this project will provide the mathematical foundation and analytical tools for certain computational problems which involve rapid oscillating microstructures. The grant will partially support graduate students as research assistants.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report

 

Partial differential equations with rapidly oscillating coefficients are used to describe various processes in media with rapidly oscillating microstructures, such as composite and perforated materials. The theory of homogenization, whose goal is to describe the macroscopic properties of microscopically inhomogeneous or heterogeneous media, shows that such strongly inhomogeneous media, whose characteristics change sharply with respect to space variables, may be approximately described via homogenized or effective homogeneous media. As such the theory of homogenization of partial differential equations with rapidly oscillating coefficients has many important applications in physics, mechanics, and modern technology.

The Project DMS-0855294 concerns the homogenization of elliptic equations and systems with rapidly oscillating periodic coefficients. In collaboration with Carlos Kenig at the University of Chicago and Fanghua Lin at the Courant Institute, the PI has made significant progress in this area. We have been able to solve several important problems, including uniform Rellich estimates, uniform boundary regularity estimates for solutions with Neumann conditions, homogenization of Green and Neumann functions, and problems of convergence rates. New techniques and approaches were developed to establish these results, which provide theoretical foundation and guidance for numerical simulations in strongly inhomogeneous media. Significant progress was also made by the PI on an open problem, arising in the study of the Navier-Stokes equations in fluid dynamics, concerning the analyticity of the semigroup generated by the Stokes operator on non-smooth domains.

The research findings were disseminated in the scientific community by the PI and his collaborators through lectures in conferences, workshops, and graduate courses as well as publishing in mathematical journals and websites. Nine journal articles were published or submitted as a result of the NSF award. The PI has been committed to the training of future generations of mathematicians. Several Ph.D. students and junior researchers were involved on the project; one Ph.D. student supported in part by the grant graduated under the PI’s supervision. The PI also taught courses on elliptic homogenization in two summer workshops for advanced graduate students and recent Ph.Ds. during the grant period.
